Derek James wrote:

>>Therefore if I was going to try and construct a
>>robust OCR network I think I'd tend towards a roving eye with quite a
>>high resolution(good enough to distinguish all of the characters anyhow)
>>that could see whole characters at a time - but then could rove (move
>>and zoom in/out) in order to frame characters within the eye's field of
>>view. 
>>    
>>
>
>Well, the problem is that as the size of the eye increases, the size
>of the controlling ANN increases exponentially.  We may try some very
>large resolution eyes, though, to see if there's a measurable increase
>in performance.
>  
>
I don't quite follow how this exponential increase in complexity comes 
about. I suppose it depends on how you set up the roving eye, I was 
thinking that the network would have something like two (x and y) 
outputs for the coordinates the eye should be looking at, the experiment 
code then supplies the appropriate image to the eye's sensor inputs. I 
actually think it would be better to decompose the problem so that one 
network guides the roving eye to scan, home in on a shape and frame in 
appropriately. A second network then is trained to actually recognise 
shapes independently of the first network.

Anyway I'm probably covering known issues so I'll leave it there and try 
and find time to read the paper you refered to.

Colin
